End of the Rainbow

By James Bithell

Don't limit yourself with the January blues. We play with pick and mix shapes, frosted glamour, iced with a bricolage of this seasons looks (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Lucy Dixon)

Champagne Charlie: For the Love of Cod

It is a truth universally acknowledged that it is difficult to love a fish

Monopoly by numbers

Monopoly by numbers

Camilla Jenkins Investigates: TV medical dramas

Picture this: a 747 Boeing 35,000 feet up. An announcement comes over the loudspeaker: "if anyone is a doctor or has medical training, please make yourself known to the cabin crew". I stride confidently into the galley where a man is collapsed on the floor

MUSEings: reinvention

And here tonight on BBC News: David Miliband has announced that he may become Vice Chair of Sunderland FC

Men's A/W 2011

Serena Kalirai looks ahead to what's in store for Men's fashion this year (Thumbnail credit Image: style.com)

Trending: 70s

The family fashion house Etro, founded by Gimmo Etro in 1968, has taken a look back to its roots for its S/S 2011 womenswear collection and stepped into shoes of the seventies where mixing patterned prints and pairing knitted jumpers with hot pants was all the rage

Louise Gray: an individual in the fashion world

Where do I begin? The task is set, but how and where do you start? No matter how high your aims may be, there must be a foundation laid in which to build on. One could argue that an artist's journey above all others is the trickiest of pathways

Censorship: a catalyst for creativity?

Edward Grande talks to Daniel Roy Connelly, creative director of a Shanghai-based theatre company, on the realities of censorship in China

Altered Beauty

In 1981, Sony presented the first camera which eliminated the need for film; Kodak, ten years later, unveiled the first commercially available DSLR camera. Digital photography, a medium of much artistic and technical versatility, was born (Thumbnail credit Image: Lara Jade @ Sarah Daw)

In Pictures: Alice in Wonderland

By James Bithell

With both the Royal Ballet and the Scottish Ballet premiering Alice in Wonderland this season, we look at the evolution of this tale

The Con of Conceptualism

The Conceptualists - hijackers of the term, 'modern art' - seek to remove all artistic conventions. Its spurious philosophical basis is that art is what we consciously make it, not limited by the oppressive constraints of form

Deputy Editor's Picks

By James Bithell

The arts scene is flourishing in the near future; here are my picks of what to see whatever your motivation, taste or time limitations

Bangs & Works: Tracing the Steps of Chicago House

Adam Bychawski talks to producer <b>DJ Nate</b> about how Chicago is once again at the forefront of House. (Thumbnail credit A footwork battle in progress)

Class of 2011

Future Sounds takes on the bands of 2011 (Thumbnail credit Hip-Hop has an Odd Future)

Up and coming

By James Bithell

Our pick of 2011's best records

Cinema is dead. Long live cinema!

The rise of 3D: Adrian Choa explores its implications for the future of film

Top 5 Ballet Movies

To celebrate the release of <em>Black Swan</em>, we look at the five greatest ballet movies

127 Hours

It's becoming clear that Danny Boyle is a man who relishes a challenge. This was none more apparent than in 2008 with <em>Slumdog Millionaire</em>, a movie shot largely on location in India with a host of local actors and a chaotic filming schedule

Black Swan

<em>Black Swan</em> sees Natalie Portman make a career defining performance as Nina, a twenty-something ballerina who pushes her body to its limits for the lead role in her company's production of Swan Lake

Caffeine, Cafes and Corporate Chains

As tea, coffee and cakes brim over into the narrow streets of York, Will Wade assesses the traditional tea room against the corporate names to which we are so accustomed (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Lucy Dixon)

Il Paradiso del Cibo

Eating at Il Paradiso is similar to eating in someone's front room. The tables are crammed together and there is a large television on the wall playing Italian football and music channels (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Justyn Hardcastle)

Pub

Described by my housemate who hails from Huddersfield as a "pub pub" (apparently this means it's a real pub) <strong>The Phoenix</strong> is another hugely enjoyable York pub (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Peter Iveson)

Best of York No.2: El Piano

This recipe is for Spanish patties, or <em>Tinas</em>; a great favourite at EL PIANO, in York and in Andalucia

Band of the Week: Yello

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Black Swan Competition

Darren Aronofsky's <em>Black Swan</em>, released on the 21st January, is set to be one of this year's hottest releases. Starring Natalie Portman as a mentally fragile ballerina, who credited with the lead role in her company's production of Swan Lake, finds herself on a dark, sexual and exhilarating downward spiral

Golden Tickets

By James Bithell

Our man on the ground <em>Tom Killingbeck </em>cherry-picks the most appealing acts blazing a trail Yorkwards this term.

The Next Three Days

Some movie stars do their best acting when they escape from the blockbusters they're normally drawn to

Band of the Week: Death

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

The King's Speech

"Contains strong language in a speech therapy context." A warning that was added after the makers of <em>The King's Speech</em> successfully lobbied to have the film's rating taken down from a 15 to a 12A, it must be one of the funniest caveats ever attached to a movie by the British Board of Film Classification
